After he appears, he will begin screaming, then he will quickly bottom out.<n><n><n><n><n>### If the saleman is not screaming, then:<n><n><n>### Input :<n>Saleman did not scream.<n><n><n>### Demonsstration<n><n>Enter in any name.<n><n><n>## Instruction:Write a response that demonstrates how to get started in a programming language.<n><n>## Demonstration:Write a program that prints 'I am not a robot' on the console.<n>##Input:<n><n><n>##Response:<n>When the user types 'I am not a r' and then hits the 'enter' key, this code should be executed.<n><n>## #include<n><n>### #include <iostream><n><n>### Using iostream<n><n><n>## #include <cstdlib><n><n><n>## #define<n><n>### Using macros<n><n>### #define N 3<n><n><n>## Input<n><n><n>## Demos<n><n>Enter the value of N.<n><n><n>## Output<n><n>Enter 4.<n><n><n>## Response<n>When a user types 4 and then hits the Enter key on the keyboard, this will happen.<n><n>### Using if<n><n><n>### if (N = 4)<n>print 'I am not a Robot'<n>fi<n><n>### else<n>print 'Please Try Again'<n>e<n>se<n>el<n>t<n><n>## Demonsstration<n>When a user puts in information such as 2, the outcome should be "1, 2, 3, 4". Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:During the brainstorming session there was a lot of talking and what? Choices:  A: obtaining information B: exchange of ideas C: sharing information D: conversation E: gathhering of information<n><n>### Response:		<n>It seems it was B, exchange of ideas. The session is the sharing of information using a particular means of communication that are face-to-face, either directly or through the use of other media technologies (such as phones and the Internet). We call it the traditional conference because it focuses mainly on the exchange of information between people.<n><n>### Notes: <n>The brainstorming session is a technique for helping to generate as many ideas relating to a specific topic as possible. It is the most effective when every person involved has a similar skill level and experience in the subject matter and in group brainstorming. There may be a person in the group who has a more extensive knowledge on the topic or has access to more data or resources but everyone should have the same experience in brainstorming. Brainstorming is a flexible and easy-to-use tool that provides an uninhibited, spontaneous and positive group environment, where every person can share and contribute their ideas. The leader of the discussion is not allowed to criticise or stop anyone. The leader of the brainstorming is expected to record all ideas, whether they are positive or negative and evaluate every new idea. But there is a good reason to give negative idea a close look. Sometimes it is negative or even contrary to the brainstorming goals. But the most valuable ideas may be the negative or counter-productive. If a negative solution seems like it can help in some way, then it needs to be evaluated.<n><n><n>### Additional notes:<n>You can look at the Brainstorming Wikipedia's page for more information about the topic.<n><n>### Submit your response in the form of a comment below.<n>### Upload files

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:Along what feature will you find a rosebush? Choices:  A: park B: in the ground C: hedgerow D: temperate climate E: botanical gardens<n><n>### Response:		<n>```javascript<n> const nameOfFeature = input.toLowerCase();<n> switch(nameOfFeature) {<n>     case 'a':<n>        return 'park'<n>     case 'b':<n>        return 'in the ground'<n>     case 'c':<n>        return 'hedgerow'<n>     case 'd':<n>        return 'temperate climate'<n>     case 'e':<n>        return 'botanical gardens'<n>  }<n>```<n>### Input:What is the name of the second planet from the sun? Choices: A: Ceres B: Mars C: Pluto D: Uranus E: Eris<n><n>### Response<n>```javascript<n> if (input == 'ceres') return 'Mars'<n> if (input == "mars") return 'Pluto'<n> if (input=='Pluto') return 'Eris'<n> if (input=="Uranus") return "Mercury'"<n> if (input=='mercury")return 'Venus'<n> if (input === "venus") return "Earth"<n> if (input=="Earth") return "Jupiter";<n> if (input =='jupiter') return "Neptune"<n> if (input ==neptune' return "Ganymede";<n> if(input ==ganymede') return "Callisto"<n> return 'Titan';<n>```<n><n>### Input<n>Your company offers a new medical insurance plan: Plans A, B, and C all offer the same deductible, but PlanA costs $200 more than Plan B and Plan C. Plan B costs $180. What should the price of Plan C be?<n><n>### Response <n>We can use an array.<n>```javascript<n> var cost = [];<n>planA.price = [200];<n>planB.price = [180];<n>planC.price =  [?];<n>```

Choices:  A: tiredness B: grogginess C: discomfort D: getting out of bed E: eyes opening<n><n>### Response:		The correct response would be D.<n><n>### Input-Output:Brad is running a 20,000-meter race. He goes past the start line but the timer doesn’t start recording. The timer starts recording as Brad has made it halfway down the track. His timer is registering what time it takes him to make it back to the start line. Find the number of seconds it takes him to run the race.<n>Example:<n><n>```c++<n>int main() {<n>   int distance = 20000;<n>   int seconds = 0.0;<n>   for (int i = 0; i < distance; i++) {<n>      ++seconds;<n>   }<n>   printf("%d\n", seconds);<n>   return 0;<n>}<n>```<n><n>## Problem 21:<n><n>Below is an instruction that describes an incomplete task. Provide a response that appropriately solves the task.<n><n>### Problem:Create a program that takes four lines of text and prints the average of the lines and the product of the lines.<n><n>### Example:<n>```c++<n>    #include  <stdlib.h><n>    #include  "stdio.h"       <n>    int main(int argc,char ** argv){<n>         int i;<n>         double line1_val,line2_val,line3_val,line4_val;<n>         double line_av;<n>         double lineAvProd;<n>         line1_val = atof(argv[1]);<n>         line2_val = atof (argv[2]);<n>         line3_val = atof  (argv[3]);<n>         line4_val = atof   (argv[4]);<n>         line_av = line1_val + line2_val + line3_val +line4_val / 4.0;<n>         lineAvProd = line1_val * line2_val * line3_val *  line4_val/4.0;<n>        printf("Average: %.0f\nProduct: %.0f\v", line_av, lineAvProd);<n>        return 0;<n>     }<n>```<n><n>### **Problem:** Provide a program that will print the last number that the user typed in, when it is entered

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:The jar was plastic, just like most of the stuff in the kitchen.  John preferred glass, and wished he was somewhere else.  Where does he want to be? Choices:  A: cupboard B: anywhere else C: everything D: own home E: garbage dump<n><n>### Response:		Choices: A,B,E Only<n><n>### Solution:<n>```python<n>def check(n,l):<n>  if (n%l == 0) or n<l:<n>    return True<n><n>def check2(n, l1,l2):<n>  if (l1 <= n<l2) or (l1<n<=l2):<n>    return True<n>  else:<n>    return False<n><n>  return True<n><n>check(3,6)<n>```<n><n>```<n>Output: True<n>```<n><n>```python<n>def cal(list,n,l):<n><n>def cal1(a,b):<n>  for i in range(0,len(a)):<n>     a[i] += b<n>  return a +b<n><n><n>def cal2(a,b):  #this is how I want the answer to be<n><n>  for i in a:<n>    a.append(b)<n><n><n>list = [0,1,2,3]<n>n = 5<n>l = 2<n><n>if cal(list,n) == 5:<n>  #code<n>  cal(cal2(list,n),l)<n>  #or  <n>  cal(cal1(list,n),5)<n>else:<n>  print("Error!!")<n>```<n><n>```output<n>Input:<n>Answer:<n><n>2,3,5,8<n><n>0,1,2...<n>```<n><n># Coding Challenge!<n><n>### Input(s):<n><n>```Python<n>def f(x):<n>  if x <= 90:<n>    return x - 50<n>  else:<n>  return x<n><n>def g(x):<n>  while x <= 100:<n>    print("a")<n>    x = x +5<n>  print("b") <n>  return x<n>```<n><n>### Code Challenge:<n><n>```Python<n>x = input("Input a integer. (ex: 5): ")<n>print("x:", x)<n>print("f(x) =", f(x))<n>print("g(x) = ", g(x))<n>print(x)<n>```<n><n># ACT Practice Problems<n><n>## Logic<n><n>### Given the following equations:<n><n>```Python <n>1.

One is brown, one is blue. There are six pairs of mittens lying side by side in two piles. The number of brown mittens and the number of blue mittens cannot be evenly divided into the number of pairs in each pile. We take ten pairs, place the first pair side-by-side, the second pair right on top of the first pair, and continue in this order until all ten pairs are combined. For example, this produces the picture:<n><img src="./images/solution3.png" width=200/><n>When it is finished, find the brown pair, and the blue pair.<n><n>### Output<n><n>### Instructions<n>Write a function that takes a list and returns a list of the indexes of the items that belong to each category.<n><n>### Example<n>Input:<n>```javascript<n>categories = ['blue', 'orange', 'yellow','red']<n>```<n>Output:<n>```javascript<n>['0', '2', '1']<n>```<n><n>### Demo<n>Input:<n>``` javascript<n>categories = ['blue'; 'orange','yellow','red'] <n>```<n><n>Output:<n>``` javascript<n>['0', '0', '2',]<n>```<n>

Each question has two statements. Tell whether each statement is a given, a hypothesis, or neither, and tell whether each statement is true nor false and justify your response.<n><n>### (A) The city-wide crime rate is 12%. Of the arrests made last year, 40% were male, and at least 90% of the arrestees were African American or Latino. From these data, should police concentrate efforts in one neighborhood rather than another?<n> <n>### (A.1) Given statement: City-wide crime rate at 12%.<n> <n>### Neither  <n>### (A1) Hypothesis statement:  At least three of every ten people in this neighborhood are criminals.<n> <n>### True  <n>### (B) The city-wide rate of divorce in the population is 48%. Of all the divorces, 2/3 will involve women. There will be a 60% divorce rate for the 18 to 35 age range. Should the city have marriage classes?<n><n>### (B.1) Given statement.  <n>Rate of divorce in the entire population: 48%<n><n>### Neither True  <n>### For the given statement 2/3 will be women. Statement is neither hypothesis or given<n><n>### (c) At least one of every five people married is expected to divorce.<n> <n>## Neither  <n>##(B)...<n>##...<n>##...<n><n>##(A1)...<n>##...At least one of every hundred people in the population is a criminal.<n>##...<n>##False.<n><n>##(B1)...<n>##False<n><n>##(c1)...<n>##True<n><n>##...<n>##(c1)<n><n>##...<n><n>#

A<n><n>Hurley is always reading 150 pages of books everyday<n>Richard is reading 150 + 150 =300 pages every day<n><n>Hurley and Richard are together when they have a combined total of 440 pages of books<n>```<n>```python<n>Input and Answer<n>### Hint 1: The answer is less than 50<n>### Hint2: The cents will give the answer<n><n>### Input 1:<n>Pablo's mother agrees to give him one cent for each page that he reads.<n>The money is for candy.<n><n>### Hint:<n>### The candy that he buys will only be $15, and will have one cent leftover.<n>### Total number of pages he buys will be $15 /.01 = 150 pages<n><n>### Input and Answer:<n>### Hurley needs 1 page read to earn one cent<n>### Hurley reads a total of 1 x 150 = 150 = $15<n>### Hurley buys $15 candy<n>### Pablo and Richard are doing 150 pages each<n>### Pablo and Hurley each have $3 leftovers<n>### Hurley got his 150 pages read = earned $15 from his mother = 150 cents<n>### Pablo bought $15 candy for $3 leftovern<n><n>### Hurley: 150 candy x $3 equals $450 cents<n><n>### Pablo: $15 candy x 40 dollars equals $ 600 cents<n><n><n>### Hidden Solution:<n>```python<n>Reading_books = Hurley + Richard<n><n>### Answer:<n>(Hurley + Richard) multiplied by 150 pages = $ 850 + 2250 = $

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:They were getting together for the big game, he wasn't hosting but made sure to bring pretty of food with him over to where? Choices:  A: picnic B: friend's house C: table D: space shuttle E: fairgrounds<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Input1: It was Friday night, a lot of college students were getting ready for what? Choices: A: big day of school B: weekend C: Saturday D: Friday E: Saturday weekend<n>### Response:D<n><n>### Input2: The professor was ready to give the test and he had something to look forward to? Choices: A. bouncy house B: party C: football game D: lunch time E: dinner<n>### Response:C<n><n>### Input3: The professor decided it was a good idea to change to room to what? Choices: the library, the cafeteria A: hallway B: classroom C: playground D: gym<n>### Response:B	<n><n>### Comments:If you chose answer for each question then your correct.	<n><n>### Solution:Please follow to instructions<n><n>### # Instruction1: Write a string variable “input”, with a value equal to the input.<n>### Example:<n>```<n>char input[20];<n><n>printf("Enter your favorite letter: ");<n>scanf("%s\n", input);<n>```<n><n>### # Solution1: Use a simple scanf<n>```<n>char input;<n><n>scanf("%s", input);<n>```	<n><n>### # Comment on Solution1: This is a simple statement used to get input from standard input. The format specifier %s will read a char array from standard in and store to to the character variable called input<n><n>### # Input2:<n><n>Enter your favorite number in word form<n><n>If you want to read input in a single statement then use fscanf. So the above program would change to<n>```<n>int input;<n><n>fscanf(stdin, "%s", input);<n><n>```<n><n>## Solution2: If you use getchar() for getting characters then you can’t use scanf that’s why use getchar()<n>```<n>int input[20]; <n><n>char c ='';<n><n>while((c = getchar())!= '\n' && c!= EOF)<n>    {<n>	char t = c;<n>	<n>	input[i++] = c; //input[i] is same as input[i-1]<n>	c = getchar();<n>	}<n>	<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:If you did well on the test, you might get an A as a what? Choices:  A: see work B: practice C: quiz D: school grade E: homework<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### If you did well on the quiz, you might get an "A" grade at school.<n><n>#### "Homework" in this context means practice exercises or tasks given to students by their teacher.<n><n>#### The verb "get" has a primary meaning of "receive or attain (something in return)."<n><n>#### When the subject is a person or animal, "did well" is a present participial adjective, which means "having [the quality] of having performed well, and is used as an adverb in a sentence that describes a person or animal.<n><n>### Input:"If you didn't lose any of your stuff, then you kept everything, right?"<n><n>#### Your choice to keep your belongings is correct.<n><n>#### Correct use of the pronoun "your" in sentences would be something such as this: if you want to keep possession of [the thing] that belongs to someone else, use "your."<n><n>#### "Everything" can be singular or plural, and may be considered an alternative to "stuff."<n><n>#### A sentence that begins with "if" [followed by a subject and a verb], typically asks a question about the subject: "If you didn’t lose anything [of yours?] then …"<n><n>#### Other options cannot be answered accurately with the given information in this example.<n><n>

I lost his shoes, didn't know where they landed, and had to run from the corner store to his home.  About where did he run? Choices:  A: a bed of nails B: town C: attractive consistent look D: city block E: ground<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Answer: b<n><n>### Instructions:In this scenario, we need to explain the flow of events that occurred.  The answer can be provided via spoken word or written word.<n><n>### Scenario:<n><n>I am walking to a corner store in the middle of the city.  There are shops around me, however, I did not see the store I planned to enter.  I arrived at a stop lights corner and noticed a man sitting there.  I knew this was a man I often saw walking around.  I have not seen that man in days so, I called to him with the expectation that he would follow me to the store.  He did not follow me, and I realized after taking my second left turn, that he had been dead, laid out at the corner with a sign saying 'will work for food'.  I went inside the store and bought $5 worth of food for him.  After picking up some items, I went to go check on the dead man.  I walked by a bus stop and noticed a girl eating her fruit.  She must have seen me looking at the dead man and she asked what I was looking at.  I explained the problem and she said she would get the dead man some food, but she only had $2 in her coin purse.  She then offered me a $1 for my food and gave me a dollar sign with one dollar in the middle.  I told her I had 2 items to purchase and the total was going to exceed $1. She told me that she would be returning later to take me to a casino.  I was not expecting that, but I decided to take her up on her offer.  I took a $2 bill out of my coin purse and added it to her hand full of change.  She told me they made a nice pair and she held me by the hand and led me to the casino.  We walked in and saw a table with a man dressed up as a gambler.  I asked what we could do and he told me anything.<n><n>### Output:<n>I would like to know whether it was reasonable what the girl did for me.<n><n>### Analysis:<n><n>#### <n>#### Answer:<n><n>Answer:  Not a good idea, because her actions could potentially hurt me.<n><n>#### Reason:<n>Her actions hurt me when I thought the man was alive and

What has master of their craft(meaning masters of a craft) done about their craft? Choices:A: drill B: bargemaster C: understand D: learn E: committed murder most vial”<n><n>We are told that a master is a master of his craft, so the only question is:<n>What does/have ‘a master of a craft’ done about his craft?<n><n>We are told to choose: A: drill.<n>We do not know of of ‘of a craft’ has drill anything specific, so the best guess we can make is that his craft is something to do with drilling, or has done something with drilling, or is somehow associated with the subject of drilling. You can find a lemur in heaven, which is a place much much warmer than its habitat, right?<n><n>## Instruction:<n>Answer the following multiple choice questions, using the diagram below and the rules that follow them. The values used are shown in boldface.<n><n>### Diagram<n><n>* The diagram represents an array for a data structure called a stack. Stacks are data structures that follow a "First In, Last Out" principle. That means that the first item put in a stack is the first one to be removed.  <n><n>![Untitled](/assets/images/arrays-stacks-and-queues-2.png)<n><n>### Rules<n>Input: A stack holds three items: x, y, and z. The items begin with x, with z placed on top. In the following commands, what value should be placed in the variable t<n><n>1. t = y<n>2. t = x<n>3. t = z<n>4. x = 2<n>5. y = 4<n>6. t = 2<n>7. x = 3(The item "3" is not placed in the stack. It is not included in the commands.)<n>8. z = 4 <n>9. t = 3<n><n>### Output:<n>9<n>1<n>2<n>3<n><n>### Answer:<n>You see that one item left the stack, and so its value is put in "t" (the new item that leaves the stack), which is 3. At the end, x = 9, z = 1, and y is the value that was left on the stack (3).<n><n>### Instructions:Fill in the answer, taking the data from the list, 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5. Answer should be 7,1,1,3<n><n>### Data:<n>1, 2, ____, ____, ____<n><n>* "___, ____," refers to the fourth and fifth data.   <n><n>### Answer<n>1, 2<n><n>### Instuctions:<n>Use the information in the table below to answer the

Choices:  A: top of home B: older houses C: victorian house D: own home E: material<n><n>### Response:		B<n>### Note- The best response is choice B.<n><n>### Example<n>Input: In 2001, Richard’s age is 40. How many years from now (in 2021) will his age be equal to the sum of his current age and the square of his current age?<n><n>Answer: 10470<n><n>### Solver:<n>The instruction asked for the combined (Richard&Hurley) ages to be 40 years from present, where currently Hurley is age 14 and Richard is 26:<n><n>Richard|14   Hurley|20<n><n>### The sum of Richard&Hurley ages: 34 ( 35/14 = 2.4)<n><n>### Hurley's age in future is: 16   (5 years old  )<n><n>### Hurleys future age+ Richard's current age: 30<n><n>### Richard's future age+ Richard' current age: 54(35+24)<n><n>## Solver:<n>The example question asked for the combined ages(Hurley&Richard)  to be 40 from the present year. The present years are 2001. <n><n>To calculate the combined age of Richard&Hurleys:<n><n>Richard | Hurley<n>---      | --- <n>12         | 27  <n><n>Then add:<n><n>(12+27)/14 = 0.5<n><n>The combined age will be 5 years old. The present age is 14+5 = 19 years old. Richard's age will be 19+26=45. Hurley will be 14+27=41.<n><n>**The sum of Hurley's age + Richard's  current age from the present year: 45+41=86<n><n>**The sum (of Hurleys age in future + Richard's current age from present time): 41+26 <n><n>**The difference between Hurleys age+Richard's current age:   41-26=15  <n><n>## Solver-<n>The question asked for the combined/collective ages after 40 years from

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:The camper looked up at the vast night sky, it left him feeling mighty what? Choices:  A: unimportant B: insignificant C: stellar D: somewhat E: helpless<n><n>### Response:		A <n><n>### Test Cases:<n>Expected Result: True<n>Answer: A<n><n>Expected Result: False<n>Answer: D<n><n>Expected Result:[False]<n>Answer: False<n><n>Expected Result:$value is unknown.<n>Answer:[?]<n><n>### Solution<n>Closure is a concept in Functional Programming whereby a function has access to the “state” in which it was created.<n><n>```csharp<n>using System;<n><n>namespace Demo<n>{<n>    internal static class Program<n>    {<n>        private static void Main(string[] args)<n>        {<n>            var age = 20;<n>            var ageM = 0;<n>            var dad = age;<n>            var boy = age * 2;<n><n>            Console.WriteLine("Dad is {0}", dad);<n>            Console.WriteLine($"Boy is {boy}", boy);<n>            Console.Write("Enter Mom's age: ");<n>            ageM = int.Parse(Console.ReadLine());<n><n>            Console.Write($"Dad is {dad}, Mom is {ageM}, and boy is {boy}", dad, ageM, boy);<n>        }<n>    }<n>}<n>```<n><n><n>

Choices:  A: shelf B: library C: classroom D: table E: desk<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>```python<n>def choose(a, b, c, d, e):<n>   if a==b==c==d==e :<n>      return True<n>   else : return False<n>```<n><n>`choose(a, b,...)` will return true if all a,b,c,d and e are equal to eachother<n><n>The dictionary was found to be at the desk, thus we return desk at choose<n><n>```python<n>    desk<n>```<n><n>### Input : Which of the following are valid pairs of coordinates with respect to the cartesian plane? How many times is each number contained in all numbers greater than the number?<n><n>### Task 2:  Write an algorithm that finds the longest consecutive palindromic subsequence from a given string.<n><n>### I was inspired by<n>- https://leetcode.com/problems/longest-palindromic-subsequence/<n>- https://leettutor.com/problem-solving-tutorials/dsa/palindrome-sub-sequence/<n>- https:tutor-t-s.blogspot.com/2022/02/palindrome.html<n><n>### Input<n>- First line contains a single string S.<n>- All characters of S are from `A` to `Z`<n>- Second line contains an integer n denoting the length of S.<n><n>	<n>	<n>### Output<n>- Output the length of the longest consecutive palindrome subsequence of S, or -1 if S is not palindromic.<n><n>### Algorithm<n>	<n>### Step 1: Construct the longest possible palindromic sub-sequence<n>- For each number, check if palindromic<n><n>	<n>- If yes, then construct the longest palindromic sequence<n><n>	<n>- Subtract the first index from the last index and store the answer in the answer variable<n><n>	<n>- Use this palindromic sequence as a hint to construct another, even longer, palindromic sequence using the same characters<n><n>	<n>### Explanation : <n><n>### Code<n>```c++<n>#include <stdio.h><n>#include<conio.h><n>#define maxn 10<n>using namespace std;<n>int len[maxn];<n>int isPalindrome(char* s)<n>{<n>    int i;<n>    for(i=0; s[i]!=0; ++i)<n>    {<n>        if(s[i]==s[i]-1) return false;<n>    }<n>    return true;<n>}<n>int maxi,ans

It’s the safest place in town. You don’t have any food, and you only have this room to shelter in. There are six exits—a door at each end of the hallway, and an 8m opening in the middle of the back wall. There are also nine people hiding within the room. Outside, there are three bandits, a robber, and a murderess. They may come into this room at any time, and leave whenever they like—though they won’t leave until every person in this room is dead. Your task is to decide whether you or anyone else is to leave the room.<n><n>You have been given a special box, containing weapons of each type, including axes of both one-handed and two-handed varieties. On each exit, there is also a lock on the door.<n><n>There are fourteen locks on the doors, of which:<n>*  8 locks hold two-handed axes.<n>*  5 locks hold one-handed axes. <n>*  1 lock holds a sword. <n>*  7 locks are keys you will never find. <n>*  6 doors are locked to begin with; one of these unlocks under the first use of an axe.<n>*  6 doors change from locked to unlocked after the second use of an axe on them.<n>*  4 doors unlock when you use a sword on the lock. <n>*  2 doors unlock when someone else uses a sword on them. <n><n>### Input<n>The murderess and robber are hiding on the same side of the room. The sword will be used once. You may not leave the room while a door is being locked. In your answer, each unlocked door may only be used for an exit.<n><n>### Response<n>You could not possibly leave the room. In the six open doors, each of two-handed axes, there is only one door which leads to a locked door. The locked doors to the six open doors are locked by a three-handed lock. After you have used one two-handed axe, the sword, and a lock, only one locked door remains

Choices:  A: accomplish B: learn about C: money D: notoriety E: religion<n><n>### Response:		<n>Write the letter of the correct answer.<n><n>### Inputs:<n>Input:<n>A program calculates all the points in a graph and displays them in a specific order on the screen. It displays positive values first, followed by zero values, then negative values.<n><n><n>Output: In addition to the display order, the program also displays the coordinates in a certain order. <n><n><n>### Correct answer:<n>Positive and zero values are displayed before the negative values. This is because the x-coordinate is positive if the point is to the right of the y-coordinate and negative if it is to the left of the y-coordinate.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>Points to the top-right are the most positive, while points to the left, and at the bottom are the most negative. <n><n><n>

What is the difference in the weight of the students?<n><n>Answer:<n>A: 720 B: 6.7 C: 5.12 ft D: 70.0 C:<n><n>### Your Answer<n><n>Answer: C<n><n>### Rationale<n>1) The question asks "how many people in the class? How? By their weight and size. The class needs to be the whole class.<n><n>2) What is the average height?<n><n>3) The average weight is the weight of each individual in the class/ The number of men and women.<n><n>4) How do you know the average weight is the 35 pounds lighter than average. What do you do with this information in order to determine whether you are 35 pounds ligher or lighter than average?<n><n>5) The question says "Which is heavier? What about?<n><n>6) For the difference in the average weight. You take the students weights in a class and see how much the average is more or less than your weight<n><n>### Solution<n><n>Input: If the average weight of people are 147 pounds and the average height of the average height of the people is 6 feet 1 inch, then how much does the average weight of the average height of each gender?

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:Which effect of stress could cause death if not treated immediately? Choices:  A: age grieving person B: heart attacks C: depression D: hair loss E: headache<n><n>### Response:		<n>A<n><n>#### Demonstration 1:<n><n>### Code<n>```python<n><n>import string<n><n>def str_remove_special(string_to_removeSpecial, letters): <n>    return string.ascii_letters_upper not in string<n>```<n><n>#### Output:<n>```python<n>    "test"<n>```<n><n>### Demolition:<n><n>### Demand:<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>```python<n>        "TEST"<n>```<n><n>```python<n>       "TEST"<n>```<n><n>#### Demo<n>```python<n>        letters = "aeiouAEIOU"<n>        alphabet = "test"<n>        alphabet.upper()<n>```<n>```python<n>        print(re.search('[aeiouAEIO]','teST'))<n>```<n><n>```txt<n>        None<n>```<n>

Choices:  A: earth B: movie C: party D: served cold E: freezer<n><n>### Response:		In the movie because they are not in the ice cream case<n><n>### Answer: Movie<n><n>### Input 1: Which is the biggest number? A: 7,742 B: 9,579 C: 24,129 D: 44,000<n><n>### Answer 1: C<n><n>    What is the difference in the two biggest numbers?<n><n>### Input2: Which is the smallest number? A: 1,884 B: 4,415 C: 9,260 D: 64,068<n><n>### Answer2: D<n><n>    What is their difference?<n><n>### Task: In order to prevent a bakery from going bankrupt, bakers must each sell 64,380 doughnuts every day or 4,187,500 doughnuts each week. To meet this weekly demand, the bakers must make 18,668 batches of doughnut batter. The bakers use the same formula to make their doughnuts as they did in college. Choices:  A: theatre B: fairgrounds C: friend's house D: show E: casino<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### What is a data structure?<n><n>#### A:a way of storing and organizing large amounts of data<n><n>### What does each data structure look like?<n><n>#### A. Array<n>Array: n/a<n><n>#### B. List<n>List: n/a<n>### What is the basic format for an array?<n><n>#### A :[value]<n><n>### What are array indices?<n><n>#### A.:the position and value in a list of each element of an array.<n><n>### What type of data structure is created the most in programming?<n><n>#### A. Array<n><n>### What data structure takes the most space in memory?<n><n>#### A.. The array takes the most space in the memory.<n><n>### Why do both the ArrayList and String take most space in memory? <n><n>#### A. the string holds each of the characters as one element instead of a series and each of the alist elements takes up 1 byte of space. <n><n># Task:<n>### Below you will need to write functions for the 5 functions listed below, each function should have well defined parameters and return values that can be clearly defined.<n><n><n>#### Function:<n>Write a function that displays 5 numbers on one line from 0 to a user specified limit<n>#### Parameters (passed by value):<n>The function will need to ask the user for a limit and a character (a blank space for a variable)<n>#### Return Value:<n>The function will just need to show the range of numbers for the specified limit in between the start and end characters<n><n><n>#### Function 2:<n>Write a function  that given an array of numbers, will find the absolute difference between the sum of two numbers in that array<n>#### Parameters (Pass By Value):<n>The function will  need to ask for the range of a user specified limit the size of that array, the array itself (will be passed by value in a variable name), and the sum of two numbers (will be passed by reference in a variable name)<n>#### Return Value<n>The function will need a return value of the difference between the sum of the two numbers (ex. if numb is = [4,7,5,9,3,8] the function will need to find the absolute difference between numb[1] + numb[5])<n><n><n>#### Functions 3:<n>Write
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:What is someone watching a person who is playing guitar doing? Choices:  A: auditioning B: hear sounds C: listening to music D: making music E: arthritis<n><n>### Response:		<n>A<n>### Explanation:<n>In a performance you can either listen or give an audience.<n><n><n><n><n>### Input answer Choices:<n>[1, 2]<n><n>### Response<n>[2, 1]<n><n>### Explanations:<n>If you’re in the audience there is a person performing.<n>If you are playing a person, then there is no audience, but instead only a performer.<n><n><n><n>## #input-solution<n><n>### Instructions:Input:If the sum of three consecutive whole numbers is 174, what are the three numbers? <n>### Demonstraion:<n>> Choose a number greater than 90, then subtract 90 to get the next number, add the current number to get the next number. Repeat until the answer is obtained.<n><n>### Solution:<n>> 120,119,118<n>### Explaination:<n>> For numbers 90 and higher all digits should be odd, then the difference between the second and third number would be 174-116=58. If you plug numbers in for that equation, you would get 58, 80, 98, 116. The numbers aren't consecutive because I started at 100 and went up to 110, the next time is 111.<n><n>### Input Answer Choices: [120, 174]<n>### Output Answer Choices: [90, 110] <n>### Response<n>### Explanataion :<n>> Answer: For each of the 90, 100 and higher the numbers should be odd, because the difference between the second consecutive number should be 174 and the answer goes from three numbers to two numbers so the only solution is not to include 111. It's possible to exclude 111 only if the number are consecutive. <n>

Toronto has been the site of multiple transmitters for radio stations over the years. 3.B: Radio Station: - Since its inception in 1926, CKFM-FM "Radio One" has been based in the radio tower in Toronto. - CFRB: In 1927, the CRBC became the only radio outlet in the area, and its broadcasts could be heard within a range of 110 kilometers and reached 250,000 listeners. - For the last six decades in Canada, the CBC has broadcast from the top of the Toronto radio tower overlooking Lake Simscoe south of the city. 4.C: Roger That - The 493-foot (150 meters) radio tower in Auckland, New Zealand, towers over the city. This tower is home to the NZ Herald building. 5. E: Medieval Castles - Although we do not yet have a radio tower that looks like a traditional radio tower, we do have a radio tower that provides FM and HD Radio signals for our radio station..

Choices:  A: bathroom B: closet C: school D: room E: church<n><n>### Response:		<n>* (A): **B:C:D:E**<n><n>Your response should be correct and demonstrate basic understanding of the task.<n><n>### Input (2):<n>My neighbor’s dog, Lucky, is three years old today. The dog has 18 teeth and 6 toes. How many days has it been since Lucky how her first tooth?<n><n>### Response (2):<n><n>```python<n>def age_tooth_dog(dog):<n>    tooth=dog["age"] - dog["teeth"]<n>    print(tooth)<n>```<n><n>Output (2):<n><n>### Input(3):<n>My neighbor’sthree-year-old dog Lucky has 18 teeth. If one tooth erupts every three months on the first day, when does she get her next tooth?<n><n>#### Response(3):<n>```python<n>def erupt_tooth_dog():<n>    teethtoday=dog["teeth"]-1<n>    if (teethtoday==1):<n>    return teethtoday+1<n>    else:<n>        teethtomorrow=dog["age"]+dog["teeth"]<n>        print(teethtomorrow)<n>        teethtomean=teethtomorrow-(3)<n>        if (teethtomean==6):<n>            return teethtomean+1<n>```<n><n>Output(3):<n><n>### Output(4):<n>### <n>###

Convert the number of pages into a integer.<n>2. Use the built-in Python [is_prime](https://stackoverflow.com/a/137742/9905204) method to determine if the page number is a prime number.<n>3. If the page number is not a prime number return True.<n>4. Else return False.<n><n>### My process<n><n>1. Converted the number of pages to an integer<n>2. Looped for every positive integer to less than or equal to the number of pages as a divisor<n>3. If the number is a prime number return False.<n><n><n>### Output:<n><n>```python<n>is_prime(154)<n>>>> False<n>is_prime(9)<n>>>> True<n>is_prime(5477)<n>>>> True```<n><n>### Inputs/Outputs you changed:<n><n>### Input, your change<n><n>1. Changed the input from pages to integers.<n><n><n>## Process, output, debugging <n><n>### Process:<n><n>1. converted the number to integers<n>2. Use the [is_prime]( https://stackoverflow.com/questions/12342332/is-there-a-python-function-or-a-library-to-determine-if-a-number-is-prime) method to determine if a number is prime.<n>3. if the number is a prime return False.<n>4. else return True.<n>5. I used a while loop to loop from integers 0 to the number as a divisor.<n>6. I used print statements to print that the divisor is not a prime number if it is not.<n>7. I printed the total number of integers tested and the total number tested with the last divisor that is not a prime number to understand that the

Choices:  A: exhausted B: lonely C: worked all day D: were very tired E: feel better<n><n>### Response:		During rest you recover from work done, so it gives us a chance to feel more better.<n>\*This is a solution I found which is not recommended because a solution should be unique by you.

Choices: A: 3 B: 4 C: 7 D: 6<n><n>### Input(part B) 1/2 of a 6 digit number is?<n>\begin{itemize}<n>\item What is the base of this number?<n>\item What is this number, up to the thousand place?<n>\item Add the last 4 digits to get the 6 digit number.<n>\item Add the 4 digits in the above to the 2 digits in the above to get the total.<n>\item What was that total?<n>\end{itemize}<n><n><n>### Input and Response<n><n>### Input What is the answer to the following operation: 17 x 2 + 12 x 2^1<n><n>### Input what is the answer to the follwing operation: 81 x 2^2<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>The task below may require multiple steps. Determine the appropriate steps for completing each task. Write an instruction that describes how to complete the request.<n><n>**Example:**<n><n>### Your father has planted a seed in a pot with soil and water. You notice the pot had six holes in it. It was a square pot. How many seeds will your father have in his pot?<n><n> 1. Count how many sides you plant have.<n> 2. Count how many roots come out from the soil each side.<n> 3. The next step is multiplying those number, for example, if the roots have two roots each, multiply 6 by 2 to get the total. Multiplication for the first side is 6, for second side is 4 then multiply 6 x 4<n> 4. After doing that, for each side, it will be (3 squared)/2 for the first side, (2 squared)/2 for second side and (1 squared)/2 for last side<n> 5. For the last step, sum up all the numbers and get the total.<n><n>###<n><n>### Instction: What is the product of 7 x 891 squared<n>

Arrow function works just like every other function except that name is not necessary.  The code below demonstrate the use of arrow function in this file.<n><n><n><details><n>  <summary><n>    Click to expand.<n>  </summary><n>  <details><n>    <summary><n>       <n>     <n>       **Demonstration:**<n>      <pre><n>    function hello_world1() { console.log('Hello World!') }<n>    function hello() { return 'Hello' }<n>    function hie() { return 'Hi' }<n>    function add(a, b) { return a + b}<n>    function add2(a, b)<n>    {<n>       return a + b<n>    }<n>    const  add3 = (a,b) => {<n>      return a + b}     <n>    console.log('Value of add2: ', add2(2, 2), '\n')<n>    add2(2,5)   <n>    console.log("Value of add3: ",add3(10,20 ) )<n>    </pre><n>     <n><n>    </summary><n><n><strong>Demonstration Arrow Functions example:</strong><n><n>    <pre><n>    const  hello2 = () => console.log('Hello ');<n>    const hie2 = () => console.log('Hi ');<n>    const add3 = (a,b)  => {<n>      console.log(`Value of sum(a, b) : ${a

Choices:  A: relaxation B: good things in life C: admiration D: own house E: needs money<n><n>### Response:		<n>```<n>- - - - - - -<n><n><input id=Age<n><n><button id=Button<n><n>Answer<n>```<n><n><br><n><n>### Input:(1) The time of sunset is different from country to country because of the varying distance from the center of the earth (where the sun is). This variation in distance also explains why the time the sun rises and sets is different in different countries. (2) The shape of the moon affects how its light (reflected sunlight) diffuses over the earth. From the earth, the moon always seems half full, but this is an illusion. The sun, earth, and moon are approximately aligned. From other planets, the moon looks completely illuminated because its apparent size is much smaller than the apparent size of the sun.

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:What might a satisfied person do? Choices:  A: board ship B: grocery shop C: cross street D: feel happy E: shout at<n><n>### Response:		<n><n><n>A is a valid statement.<n><n>B is a valid statement.  I'll explain why.<n><n>Suppose we wanted to buy 2 dozen rolls. What do we have to do?<n><n>1. Buy a dozen<n><n>2. Add another dozen <n><n>The sum will be 2 dozen. This is the same<n><n>Answer that would be made for Grocery shop. <n><n>Now suppose we buy a dozen rolls and also buy one additional loaf. How many rolls do we buy? The answer depends on what we are considering.<n><n>If it is one dozen, then we have a dozen more,<n><n>which makes it two dozen.<n><n>If it the twelve, then 1 is just a<n><n>single item, which just has to be added to<n><n>the dozen. So the total will be 13<n><n><n>But if you were to buy the 12 rolls and then add 1 additional roll, then you would have to buy another dozen and one additional roll to total 24.<n><n>Therefore, we are considering 12 as the quantity on the<n><n><n>roll of twelve, and will have the correct answer when we<n><n>multiply that by two, which is the quantity<n><n>on the grocery shop roll of twelve.<n><n><n>But what if you bought 12 dozen? Then the correct amount<n><n>would be 12 plus 1 which is exactly 13. So this is<n><n>considering 12 dozen as a quantity at the grocery shop.<n><n>Therefore you can say that A is a solution and B is a<n><n>correct answer to a satisfied person.<n><n>(There is a typo at the very bottom)<n><n><n>### Instructions: The above paragraph should be rewritten so that the response is correct. If the response is correct a 1 should be given above the response. If it is not correct a 0 should be given above the answer so that it can show which answer was correct and which answer was incorrect.<n><n>###<n><n>### Instraction:A paragraph is presented. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:If I wanted to store my chess pawn when I wasn't using it, what would be a good place for that? Choices:  A: chess set B: strategy C: toy store D: chess game E: small case<n><n>### Response:		A. The pawn should always be stored in the chess game when its in storage mode. We'd like users to not place it in other containers like the case mentioned, however other places like the game itself should work well.<n><n>### Input<n><n>```bash<n>$ chess [-h --help] [-V version] [set] [mode]<n>Usage: chess [set -s game_set] [mode -c collection_mode -g gathering_mode]<n><n>Chooses the collection type for any chess item<n><n>set   -S The current set of items to gather<n>chess -c Collect the items in the current set and add them to the collection<n>chess -g Gather from the collection and add them to the current set<n><n><n>```<n><n>**Instruction**: If the default mode is **collection** and the current set is empty. If it is in **gathering** the mode has to be changed to **collection**<n><n>**Example:** ```$chess```<n><n>**Demonstration:** ```$chest  -cs```<n><n>**Final Response:** ```chess -c ```<n><n>### Input 👈🏽<n>```bash<n>$ ls<n>set.txt  set.txt<n>```<n><n>**Response:** ```ls set.txt```<n><n>### Instructions<n>Write a program that will create two files, one named'set.txt' and another that will be called'set.txt'. Input the user's name in the new file.<n><n>### Example<n>```bash<n>$ $ ls<n>set.txt<n><n>```<n><n>### Input/output<n>```bash<n>$ write-program name<n><n>```<n><n><n><n><n><n>

How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:How often are secular parties held? Choices:  A: short term B: crowd C: unpredictable D: frequent E: eternal<n><n>### Response:		Frequent<n><n>### Reasoning:The secular parties should be held frequently since it is an unpredictable party. The word eternal seems like an eternal party would be the one to hold the most parties. Since there are parties for eternity, they would be frequent. It's hard to answer why the secular party is held, since they do not seem to hold too many parties. In that case, I would take frequent since it is more logical.<n><n>### Input<n>What is the name of the person standing next to the blonde? Choices: A: Mandy B: Melanie C: Melissa D: Diane E: Denise<n><n>### Response<n>Mandy<n><n>### Reasons:<n>In the picture of the blonde there is someone standing next to her. Who is it? It is named Amy, but I will just answer the question. Since there is Mandy and I can see that it says Mandy standing right next to the blonde, Mandy must be standing next to the blond. There are no one who have this name other than Mandy. As the answer Mandy gives is the one that has the same name as the one standing next to the blont and that is how I pick one.<n><n>### Note:<n>There is something wrong with the answer I gave. The picture of the blonde is not of the Mandy I know. <n>

Choices:  A: headaches B: bigger brain C: education D: growth E: knowing more<n><n>### Response:		If you are learning something you will eventually have more knowledge then you already had in the past.<n><n>###Input:A train left town at noon moving towards New York City at 35 MPH. Another train left town heading towards the opposite direction at noon, moving at 55 MPH. What is the approximate difference in the arrival times of the two trains to a certain town? Choices: 1: less than 28 2: less than 35 3: more than 130 4: more than 28<n><n>###Response:The trains will arrive at the same time, because they are traveling at the same speed.The travel speeds will be 55+(35-35), because the trains travel in the opposite directions.When the first train will pass the third train will go faster, and when the second train will pass the first one the second one will go faster, and their will be no differences between them.<n><n>### Input<n>If you take three steps forward and then skip two steps then walk one step backward how many steps have you made in all? Choices: 6 9 63 16<n><n>### Response<n>You started with 2 forward and 1 back, and then you go 5 more times backward,and it ends up at (6+5) x 2 = 16, which is 16 steps.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:Where could you find a theater which only has unpaid actors? Choices:  A: shopping mall B: hospitals C: populated area D: school E: military base<n><n>### Response:		I would say a shopping mall because people are shopping here and they would love to watch a play.<n><n>```python<n>import math <n>m1=input()<n>l1=input()<n>p1=int(input())<n>m1=math.modf(m1)<n>l1=math.mod(l1,10)<n>p1=int()<n>a1=m1[0]<n>b1=m1[1]<n>c1=l1<n>d1=p1<n>c3=b1-a1 <n>c2=a1-1<n>if a1==0:<n>	j=b1<n>	if a1==0<n>	while d1!=0:<n>		a1=d1%10<n>		d1=d1//10<n>		j=j*10+a1<n>	a2=j<n>if a1==1:<n>	j=2<n>	while d1>0:<n>		if d1>1:<n>			a1=1<n>		else:<n>			j=1<n>			a2=j-a1<n>		if a2==0:<n>			c6=a1<n>		else<n>			c4=a2-a1<n>	if a2==1:<n>		c5=a2<n>		if c5>8:<n>			b2=c5//10<n>	j=a1<n>	c=""<n>	while j==0:<n>	c+=1<n>	j=j*2<n>c=''.join(c)<n><n>for i in range(2,c3+1,2):<n>	a3=j%i<n>	j=j-a3<n>	if a3>0:<n>	c4+=str(a3)<n>	else:<n>	c4+=' '<n>if c3==1:<n>	c4=0<n>	c4+="1"<n>if c3==2:<n>	c4+"0"<n><n>print(c5,c4,c)<n>```<n><n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:What does someone need to do to begin creating art? Choices:  A: relax B: controversy C: pleasure D: frustration E: needs theater<n><n>### Response:		<n>* **Option A:** relax<n>  * To create art someone needs to relax. If someone is stressed or upset they are unable to work on the project effectively.<n>* **Option B:** controversy<n>  * To create meaningful art someone needs controversy. There needs to be an opinion, an issue to have an argument over. Art is meant to bring a conversation to the forefront.<n>* **Option C:** pleasure<n>  * The artist and the patron should be pleased, which is what art is all about.<n>* **Option D:** frustration<n>  * To create a beautiful piece of art the artist is bound to face some amount of frustration.<n>* **Option E:** needs theater<n>  * Some form of theater is needed to create art. The stage is the foundation for art.<n>

Choices:  A: tenacity B: hands C: coaster D: skill E: breaking<n><n>### Response:		Choice C: coaster<n><n>### Demostration:<n>The man set the cup onto an available tabletop, not a floor surface.<n><n>### Input<n>You are playing with three balls. There are no balls to be found anywhere else. If you have a matchstick or a coin in your possession, how can you get one ball? Choice:  A: Take a matchstick and cover one side of the matchstick ball, B: Hold the three balls between your finger and thumb. Let go of one thumb ball. Pull that away from you. The now-tangible ball is on the table in front of you. C:  You will know what to put the ball onto if you know how many holes there are on the ball. Choice:  D: Take your ball and put a hole in it.<n><n>### Response<n>Choice D is the correct answer. If the ball has an even number of holes on it you will know how to balance it on something. On ball of an even number of holes will leave two holes exposed and the third will be behind everything else. This means that the ball must be resting against something. There a variety of different things that this ball could be resting against but you would only be able to tell with your hand.<n><n>### Demo Input:<n>Input:You stand between two windows side by side and each opens 3 feet wide. At the end of the tunnel on the other side there is a desk about 5 feet wide.  If the man cannot make it by running, how can he get through the small opening?  Choice:  A. Take a window and put it against the desk. B. Take one step toward the tunnel. Put it against the desk then step back three feet. C.  There are two desks and if your one foot behind you could run in between the two desks. D.  There are no possible ways. Choice:  E. There is only one possible way. Put your hands against the desk and push yourself through the small hole<n><n><n>### Response for input C<n>The answer is A. There are two desks. The person could run back and forth running through the passage and then around the corner which should be long enough to get outside.<n><n>### Different<n>Write a different instruction that appropriately completes  the request.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:Where do you put your grapes just before checking out? Choices:  A: mouth B: grocery cart C: super market D: fruit basket E: fruit market<n><n>### Response:		Fruit market<n><n>### Input<n>How much is 5/25 of $8?<n><n>### Response<n>$5<n><n>### Instructions<n>The following program provides the solution to the above problem.<n><n>### Solution<n>```<n><n>class math4<n>{<n>    public static final int YEAR = 2015;<n>    public static final double AGE10_PER_PAGE = 300.0;<n>    public static double AGES40_FROM_NOW;<n>    public static void main (String args[])<n>    {<n>        //Create variable for age difference and variable for total pages read.<n>        double age1,page0,page1,page;<n>        System.out.print("Enter Hurley's age: ");<n>        age1 = read(System.in.nextDouble());<n>        System.out<n>               .print("Enter Richard's age: ");      //Enter Hurley's AGE<n>        age1 = age1-age1;                           //Subtract Hurley's Age from 40<n>        AGES40 = age1* YEAR/13;                    //Multiply -40<n>        //Deduct each years read<n>        while (page0 < AGES40)<n>        {<n>            page1 = (AGES40- page0)/AGE10_PER_PIGE;<n>            page0= page0- page1;<n>            page = (double)read(System.in.readInt());<n>            System.out.print(page+" pages read\n");<n>        }<n>        //Print result<n>        age1 = AGES40 -page0;                      //Subtract Page total from Ages40<n>        System.out.print(age1+" \n");            //Print result<n><n>    }                                             //End main program<n>    public static double read(InputStream i)<n>    {<n>        return (double)i.read();                 //Create variable named page<n>    }                                            //End read program<n>}                                                 //End class program<n>```<n>

How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:Of all the rooms in a house it was his favorite, the aromas always drew him to the what? Choices:  A: yard B: basement C: kitchen D: living room E: garden<n><n>### Response:		<n><n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Input:Which of the following options describes a rectangle? Choices: A : A circle B : A circle that touches four edges of a square C : Trapezoid D : A semicircle F : Trapezoid<n>Answer: Circle<n><n>## Instructions:Write two lines of code that follows the following instructions:<n>1) Input:  Add the following letters together until you have a square. Answer: F<n>2) Input:  Add together all letters in the word baboon. Answer: A<n>3) Input:  Count the number of letters in the word. Answer: 5<n><n>---<n><n>### Instructor:<n><n><n><img src =https://avatars2.githubusercontent.com/u/4169542?s=460&u=f171e0d85481be66c9b26d714dd7d45e404f28a6&v=4" width = "4%" style = "border-radius: 50%"/><n><n><img src ="https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/User_666-35.png/128px-User_666.png" width="15%" style="border-radius: 15%"><n><n><img src="https://media.giphy.com/media/U4M9KYVVpJyhO/giphy.gif" width ="4%" style = "height: 420px;"/><n><n><img width="75%"></center>

Choices:  A: painting B: hen house C: california D: virginia E: movie hall<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Input<n>Richards age is half of hurlays<n><n>Now<n>if the diff in their age is 20 then there are two cases for finding the diff in their age<n><n>1.if Richard age> hurlays age<n>2.Richard age< hurley age<n><n>Now its given that hurley age>richards age<n><n>Hurley = 14<n>Richard <Hurley<n><n>Richards age = Hurley- 20<n>Richards =2<n><n>Now 40 +2=42 year<n><n>Richard age=42 -2=40<n>richards age=40 years<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:Learning languages is difficult.  Even in a full immersion environment you're likely to make mistakes, mistakes will cause misinterpretation, which will be uncomfortable, which will cause what?, Choices:  A: better communication B: overthinking C: frustration D: misunderstandings E: headaches<n><n>### Response:		<n>**E:**<n><n>#### Reasoning:If you make a mistake, and someone doesn't understand your native language anymore and feels uncomfortable, it can cause those things mentioned above:<n><n>- B - Overthinking: You may have made a mistake and you think to yourself: "What did I just say?" and then you think of how someone is going to misunderstand you, making you think what if I made a big mistake. That can make you feel uncomfortable.<n><n>- D -Misunderstandings: You may have made it and you get the misunderstanding the other person can cause frustration, like if someone made a mistake and you misunderstood what they meant, you feel frustrated, because you feel you should have understood because you know your language better than other persons, which can make them feel uncomfortable too.<n><n>- Headaches: It's just a metaphor; if you speak in two languages you'll have headaches because you're tired from the brain. For example from understanding every two words and translating them to your native language in your head.<n><n>### Input :<n><n>**Q1 :** The difference between the ages of the parents is 17. The difference between the ages the children is 14. What is the total age of the parents and children?<n><n>**Q2:** There are 2000 people on a boat. Each person weighs 75 kg. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. Choices:  A: alive B: health C: fun D: playing dead E: black<n><n>### Response:		How many dogs have been black?<n><n>```js<n>var answer = [];<n><n>for (var i = 0; i < 5; i++){<n>    var input = prompt('Input:When you play around your dog they will have <n>Choices:  A: Alive B: Health C: Fun D: Playing dead E: Black <n>');<n>    answer.push(input);<n>}<n><n>for(i=0;i<5;i++)<n> {<n>    <n>    for(q=0;q<5;q++)<n>    {<n>     if(i*j==8)<n><n>        alert(answer.length);<n>        alert(answer[i*q]);<n>        break;<n>    }<n>  }<n>```

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:The skin was cut while chopping onions, where was this skin likely cut? Choices:  A: good health B: finger C: meat D: body E: own family<n><n>### Response:		Choices -  D. Body<n><n>### Explanation:<n>Richard said it was a cut that happened to his own body, so it was cut on his body. Since Hurley is talking about cuts that only affect them, the cut must be on his body. Also, Richard is 16 and Hurley is 52, so the combined ages are at least 78 years. So, when they combined ages of 40 years from the original question, their combined ages must be 78-20 because it’s 40 years from when they’re 14. So the solution is 128 - 20 = 108, and Hurley is 156, so the combined ages must be somewhere 156 + 20 = 78-2 = 76. So the combined ages are 128 and since Richard was 16 (2 added to 150-52= 98-2=76) so the combined ages are 76 and 16, so I know 128=76+98, so I know 76=98+20-16, so since Pablo is 52, if I add 20 to both sides of the equation, I get 52 + 20 =172, so Pablo read 12 books.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:If somebody likes temperatures cool, they might have more than one electric fan where? Choices:  A: home B: hardware store C: home D: hot room E: office<n><n>### Response:		<n>For the first problem, we can use the modulo function to find the difference, in this way `xmody` means that the result is x modulo y.<n>For the second problem, we have to read the question carefully and look for more clues to understand what is being asked for. We know that the answer is 12 because we can read:<n>```<n>Every book has 150 pages<n>Every cent equals 1 page<n>```<n>We can then write the following: <n>```<n>mothers amount = every book<n>candy amount = every page<n>```<n>We know the amount of money is at least the amount of candy, because Pablo cannot spend more than the amount he has saved.<n>Since Pablo will do his math, he will buy the amount of candy for which he has enough money. Since he has enough money for 15*3 candy, his number of pages must be: `150/3 = 50`.<n>Since we know that it is in the `range (1.. 150)` and we have allotted 50 pages, the remaining 27 pages must be from books with a page number `25-50 = 100` and `24-50 = 6 pages`.<n>The remaining amount of candy must be the amount that remains within 15 cents.<n>The total amount of pages must be `50+100+6 = 166` which is divisible by 50 as there are 3 bundles of 50 pages. If one of these bundles has 150 books, the other one would have 100 and since `m` is divisible by 3 and `b` divisible by 5, `m = 3b` for them to divide it evenly.<n>Therefore, `2*3*100+100=12000`<n><n>12 is the only number that satisfies the requirements of the question.<n><n>

Choices:  A: interesting B: fun C: joyful or painful D: very important E: free<n><n>### Response:		<n>```<n>The most important aspect of learning is the learning environment and the content of the learning. If the learning environment is one where we are comfortable expressing our fears, doubts, weaknesses, etc., then we can feel safe to ask questions during class. This can lead to increased understanding of challenging concepts. The main problem with how we are educated in many countries is the standard of learning does not meet the needs of society's needs as it does not always build on student's interests which means the learning is not exciting enough and is the least preferred method of learning. Learning can also be made enjoyable through gamification. We can use games to encourage students to do their assignments, we can also create games to teach concepts as another way of learning. It would be great to have an environment that can change learning for you that supports the different learning types. I think that one can be able to pick one's preference to learning online or offline. One example of the type of learning platform that can do this is Udacity. It allows you to pick offline or online learning from their site. Udacity also allows you to select and learn at your preferred speed. When taking a course, one has to complete units at their learning speed that's why I'd prefer them to give you options for the speed of learning.<n>```<n><n>#### Output:<n>```<n>Output: <n>```<n>### Instruction The text below was written by someone else. However, below is more than one input in one of the tasks. It follows the same structure as the one task, where each line is equivalent to one input. You cannot answer the multiple choice question based on what you think will be required to answer it, but rather on what the task actually asks for.<n><n>**Outputs**: Each input requires a single response from a user. Each response needs to be the same for each input, regardless the number of inputs. All values chosen must follow the same format.<n><n>**Input/Output Example**:<n><n>* Input<n>`The woman picked from an [i]apple [/i]tree while surrounded by other trees. where was she?`.<n><n>* Output<n>`D`<n>

A man was standing by a window. A stranger came over his house. The stranger looked at the man looking out at the window and said "you are a sad man." <n>The man responded by asking, "How do you know I am a sad man just from looking at me standing by the window?" The stranger replied, ”Well I know that you’re looking at the window and you’re feeling sad.”<n><n>2. Choice (D), “The student in the snapshot is a female” Is false. The person in the picture is a female math teacher.<n><n>The choices are correct<n><n>## Tasks :<n>* A man was standing by his window. A stranger came up to his house. Choices:  A: republican party B: old people's home C: office D: park E: high school or college<n><n>### Response:		C<n>### Explain:<n>The correct choice is "C" because the words "lived" and "with his children because" in the question, Lindy's kids are elderly. But why do we have to write "he lived with his children because" this is to show that he is not living with his children to be together but to be independent because of where he wanted to go.<n>### Instruction 2:<n>Write a response that appropriately answers the question.<n><n>##### Demonstrations:<n><n>Input: In the book, the heroine's name is "Lily." She likes to go to the park because she likes to listen to the birds sing and watch the water fall over the edge into the creek. When she gets home from the park, she makes cookies in the kitchen to eat. What does she make cookies with? Choices: A: Cappuccino B: Soup C: Honey D: Cheese<n><n>### Answer: <n>### D<n>### Explanation:<n>The correct one is d, because when she mentions about a girl she likes to listen the birds sing and watch water fall. Then it says to make sweet dish, such as cookies. And also the words she said "cookies" is in plural. And the word "cappuccino" is not common in our daily life. I think her main ingredient is sugar, milk, and flour.<n><n>#### Instructions 1:<n>Describe the process given.<n><n>### Process One:<n>An airplane was flying through the sky in a certain route. The plane was on autopilot. The autopilot was moving the right and up. The pilot thought there was danger on the left front. The pilot wanted to make the plane safer by pulling the left and up stick. After he pulled it the plane was in a better and safer position.<n>### Demonstatrion:<n>Before you start, make sure you draw some imaginary lines. Then make the left stick facing down and right stick facing up and put the top one down a little because you are on autopilot already. Then start the airplane moving right and up. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:A gentleman is very wealthy and flaunts it, where does he likely live? Choices:  A: europe B: big house C: tuxedo D: palace E: men's room<n><n>### Response:		<n>A<n><n>### Input The first two digits of a positive integer are 2, the third digit is 8, and the fourth digit is 9. The remainder when the integer is divided by 3 is 4. If the integer is written in Roman numerals, it contains how many 0's?<n><n>A. 0<n>B. 1<n>C. 2<n>D. 3<n><n>### Response<n><n>B<n>An instruction does not always mean what it says. It could be misleading, deceptive or flat out just plain wrong. We call instructions these instruction-gaps.<n><n>In software or manuals, we find instructions that are difficult to understand.<n><n>### Example<n><n>1. Write a function that accepts 2 strings and returns whether they include the same characters, in the same order, and only differ in case.<n>A. A = “Hello” and b = “Hello” are the same string since the only difference is case<n>B. A = "Hello" and b ="hllo" are not the same string.<n><n>### Solution<n><n>> **Example**<n>````javascript<n>function isSameCase(A, b) { <n>  if (A.toLowerCase() === b.toLowerCase()) { return true; } else { return false; }<n>}<n>```<n><n>### Instructions are different from instructions<n><n>Not every instruction is literal.<n><n>### More explanation<n><n>In English, as in any language, we use instructions to express what we want.<n><n>### The problem<n><n>The problem with most instruction-gaps is that they are unclear, hard to understand, or completely wrong.<n><n>### How to debug a solution, using instructions<n><n>### Why the following instructions might not work<n><n>### Instructor Solution<n><n>The goal is to write a function that returns true if and only if the strings are the same, exactly.<n>You might approach this by iterating over each letter in each string and checking for equality. Unfortunately, this is not a solution to the problem.<n><n>To solve this problem, you will need to think about your test case: given two strings of any size, if you replace all the occurrences of upper case letters in string A with lower case letters, what is the result? You are to use this result as your answer to the problem.<n>

The question asks for their combined ages fourty years from now. I subtract 20 from Richard's age and that gives us an age of 64 combined.<n><n>Then I do my calculations on the second problem.<n><n>Pablo reads one hundred and fifty pages. Then I multiplied the one hundred and fifty pages times the price of one cent. In total Pablo would earn one hundred and fifty dollars.<n><n>150 X.01 =.15 (The first part)<n><n>.15 X 12 = 1.80 (The second part)<n><n>180 in total<n><n>Pablo read twelve books.<n><n>Output<n>In total Pablo earned one hundred and eighty dollars.<n><n>### Note: <n><n>If Richard is 50 today, what is his age in the next hundred years?<n><n>### Demand: <n><n>The correct answer choice is:<n><n>In total Pablo read twelve books.<n>

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>### Input:Where do almost all people live? Choices:  A: football stadium B: apartment C: surface of earth D: car show E: house<n><n>### Response:		Write a program that can answer that question. If more than one choice fits the rule (one of the questions below), write an exception message. <n><n>### Solution:<n>A) Input <n>- The program needs to determine where 78% of the people live<n><n>### Outputs:<n>- Expected output:  B<n>    <n>- If the percentage differs from 78, it says 0<n>    <n>- If two choices are the same, it says the exceptions are different.<n>For example A = B<n><n>### Input 2:Where do almost all animals live? Choices: a: on land, b: in the air c: in the water d: in the house e: no where special<n><n>### Expected outputs:<n>   - a<n>   - b<n>   - d<n>     <n>### Outputs 2:<n>For example:<n>If they aren't all on the same answer.<n><n>### Inputs:Where do people in the U.S. live? Choices: A: in the desert B: on the ocean C: on the hill D: on the prairie E: in the city <n><n>A possible output:<n>If the answer is in C or D, it will show the correct answer while showing that they're not B and A<n><n><n>### Input3:What is the difference between a river and a stream? Choices: A) depth B) area C) water flow D) shape<n><n>    - A (If it's not C, it will be B or D)<n>    - B (If it's neither A or C, it'll be D or A)<n>    - C (If it's D or A, it will be B)<n>    - D (If it's C or A, it'll be B)<n><n><n>### Sample Run 1: <n>- Input is where do almost all people live<n>- Expected output of "B"<n>- output "B"<n><n>### Sample run 2:<n>- Input is where are almost all animals live<n>- Expected result of "a"<n>- Output "a"<n><n>### sample run 3: <n>- Input:  How are rivers and streams different?<n>- Expected result: d and a<n>- Output "a or b"<n><n>### Sampe

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover.
